p: Respiratory diseases have been considered to contribute to the global burden of disease in the last two decades. Lung diseases that have attributed to global mortality rates include lower respiratory infection, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), lung cancer, tuberculosis and pneumonia infection. According to the World Health Organization, by 2030, morbidity rates due to respiratory diseases may increase based on the rise of air pollution, chronic respiratory problems and respiratory infections associated with all health-related issues worldwide. Despite an alarming increase in this issue worldwide, the complexity of chronic airway or lung inflammation remains a serious limitation in establishing a clear understanding of such diseases ( 1).
